texts.definition: Navigation through gameplay environments through bodily movement.
markups: <style="Definition">Navigation through gameplay environments through bodily movement.</style>

Movement and navigation are common occurrences in games. While they in many games are done symbolically through moving characters through fictive environments, some games instead have players do <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> through requiring them to move their own bodies through a physical environment as part of the gameplay.

While many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> include physical movement, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Orienteering">Orienteering</link></style> is the prime example of one that also requires navigation. The navigation required in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Geocaching">Geocaching</link></style> relatively easy in contrast since GPS use is part of the activity. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/BotFighters">BotFighters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pirates!">Pirates!</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Treasure">Treasure</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Uncle%20Roy%20All%20Around%20You">Uncle Roy All Around You</link></style> are all games that rely less on making players move to specific locations but nevertheless require players to navigate in physical environments.

Quite naturally, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin">Assassin</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragonbane">Dragonbane</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trenne%20Byar">Trenne Byar</link></style> require some level of <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> since they are played in large areas that players need to traverse.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Human%20PacMan">Human PacMan</link></style> re-interprets <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> by making players embody all the characters and thereby force them to do <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> to play the game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ConQwest">ConQwest</link></style> also makes players do <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style>, but in this case teams of players need to more huge game pieces around a city. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pok%C3%A9mon%20Go">Pokémon Go</link></style> requires players to move around to find gyms, Pokéballs, and Pokémons.

On a general level, <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> in a game is the combination of <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="real-world-gameplay-spaces">Real World Gameplay Spaces</link></style>. More specifically, it also requires goal locations and challenges to reaching these. While the challenges are more or less the same as for any <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-physical-prowess">Player Physical Prowess</link></style> may become a gameplay feature unless explicitly design against (through for example avoiding <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>). In contrast, the goal locations nearly always have additional characteristics due to the real world consequences of using <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-artifact-proximity">Player-Artifact Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-avatar-proximity">Player-Avatar Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="player-player-proximity">Player-Player Proximity</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="robotic-players">Robotic Players</link></style> provide the possibility for <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style>.
<style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> is a primary example of where players use their own bodies as interfaces for the game.

<style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> is a form of <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style> and changes the way <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> function since players can use all their sensory abilities and are limited by their own physical abilities. Having previous knowledge of the area to be navigated is an example of <style="Link"><link="real-world-knowledge-advantages">Real World Knowledge Advantages</link></style>, and one that is likely to appear in games using <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style>.

Since it is a real world activity to move and navigate, <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> instantiates the pattern <style="Link"><link="real-life-activities-affect-game-state">Real Life Activities Affect Game State</link></style> when present. Since the reason why someone moves in an environment can be difficult to perceive, <style="CurrentLink">Physical Navigation</style> is one of the most accessible ways of creating <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive Gameplay</link></style> as long as the speed of moving can fit within what is socially acceptable.
